examples.en: That's thanks to help of my father.
examples.ja: 父の助力のおかげです。

examples.en: This was only possible with the help of others.
examples.ja: 他人の助力が有ったから出来たことです。

examples.en: With the help of a friend, it seems like I can get out of college after four years.
examples.ja: 友人の助力で、四年間で大学を出ることが出来そうです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>help</kanji> with your <kanji>power</kanji>, you are providing <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>support</vocabulary>.

Note that this is a formal word that’s mostly used in professional situations. It implies that someone has done something substantial for you.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

You really need some <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary> with this <reading>lock</reading> (りょく). You are certain that world peace and eternal happiness lie behind this one lock. But no one is willing to <vocabulary>support</vocabulary> you in opening it. What a cruel world.

examples.en: It’s so disappointing that he is lacking in originality.
examples.ja: 彼が独創性に欠けていることは非常に残念です。

examples.en: The more creative your idea is, the more people come out against it.
examples.ja: アイディアが独創的であれば独創的であるほど、反対する人も多いよね。

examples.en: WaniKani is President Koichi's original creation.
examples.ja: ワニカニはコウイチ社長の独創です。

meaning_mnemonic:
You are <kanji>alone</kanji> in what you are able to <kanji>create</kanji>. Nobody else can create like you. So what you create is your own <vocabulary>original creation</vocabulary>.

独創 refers to the act of <vocabulary>creating something original</vocabulary>, or the resulting creation itself. This word is quite formal, and generally used as 独創的 (original) or 独創性 (originality).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is watching the broadcast of the Academy Awards ceremony and sinking into the sofa.
examples.ja: 彼はソファに身を沈めながら、アカデミー賞の授賞式の生中継を観ています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sink</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sink something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to submerge something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. So instead of describing something sinking on its own, you use 沈める when you sink an enemy ship or submerge yourself in a bathtub. 

You know this because you can't sink anything until you get that <reading>mail</reading> (める) saying, "Yes, proceed with sinking!" You've got to have that mail if you want to sink something, or else everyone will blame you for the missing ship — or for you disappearing under the water.
reading_mnemonic: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "<reading>she's</reading> (しず) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.

examples.en: The cell phone strap is so gross just thinking about it makes me puke.
examples.ja: あの携帯ストラップが気色悪すぎて、考えるだけでも吐きそうだわ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 携帯 refers to a mobile phone? This is a <kanji>strap</kanji> (ストラップ) for a mobile phone, making this a <vocabulary>cell phone strap</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone strap</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 携帯.

examples.en: I’ve been afraid of dogs since I was bitten by one when I was three, but I’ve overcome my hatred for them since meeting this little puppy.
examples.ja: 三歳の頃犬に噛まれてから、ずっと犬に恐怖心を抱いていたんですが、この小さな仔犬に出会って犬嫌いを克服しました。

meaning_mnemonic: 克服 is "conquest" so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to conquer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The philosopher had to hang on to his beret as he walked through the strong wind.
examples.ja: その哲学者は強風を通って歩いたので、自分のベレー帽をしっかりと掴まなくてはならなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>philosophy</kanji> <kanji>scholar</kanji> (学者) is someone who studies philosophy. They're known as a <vocabulary>philosopher</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My sister is anorexic and when wearing her mourning dress, she looked even skinnier.
examples.ja: 私の妹は拒食症なのですが、喪服を着ているとより一層痩せ細ってみえました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>mourning</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> is your <vocabulary>mourning dress</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mourning clothes</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the on'yomi for 服 and the kun'yomi for 喪, which you learned with the word 喪. You should know how to read this word!

examples.en: The arm‐wrestling challenger crushed an apple in his right hand, showing off the strength of his right hand.
examples.ja: 腕相撲の挑戦者は、握力を見せつけるために、右手で林檎を潰してみせました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>challenge</kanji> (挑戦) <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who is going to challenge you. They are <vocabulary>a challenger</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Fried donuts, fried bananas, fried dumplings… I just love deep-fried food.
examples.ja: 揚げドーナツ、揚げバナナ、揚げギョーザ…。とにかく揚げ物が大好きなんです。

examples.en: Today's main dish in the omakase course is "fried fish with sweet vinegar ankake sauce."
examples.ja: 本日のおまかせコースのメイン料理は「揚げ魚の甘酢あんかけ」です。

examples.en: When she cooks, any food turns into beautiful, delicious, golden deep-fried food.
examples.ja: どんな食べ物でも、彼女の手にかかれば、美しく美味しい金色の揚げ物になりますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 揚げる means "to deep fry"? This is the prefix or suffix version of that word, making it <vocabulary>deep-fried</vocabulary>...

Note that 揚げ can sometimes be used as a standalone word, in which case it usually refers to deep-fried tofu.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 揚げる as well.

examples.en: Angry Koichi banged on the desk with his clenched fists.
examples.ja: 怒ったコウイチは、握り拳で机をバンバン叩いた。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 握る is "to grasp"? This is the noun version, making it a <vocabulary>grip</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 握る, so get a grip on that!

examples.en: Viet held onto the branch because Koichi shook the tree.
examples.ja: コウイチが木を揺さぶったので、ビエットは枝に掴まった。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 揺る.

examples.en: It seems that my uncle shook a tree with a beehive in it because he had never been stung by a bee and wanted to try it out.
examples.ja: 僕の伯父さんは、今まで蜂に刺されたことがなくて、どんなものか試してみたかったから、蜂の巣がある木を揺すったんだそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Shake</kanji> plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rock</vocabulary> slowly.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 揺る.

examples.en: The swings at the park swayed in the wind.
examples.ja: 公園のブランコが風で揺れた。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 揺る which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it <vocabulary>to be shaken</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be jolted</vocabulary>. You know this because it's really <reading>rare</reading> (れる) for you to be shaken like this.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 揺る.

examples.en: My kid was really looking forward to the kindergarten sleepover, but he got a cold and I just made him take antibiotics. So, sadly, he'll be absent tonight.
examples.ja: うちの子、幼稚園のお泊まり会をすごく楽しみにしてたんだけど、風邪を引いちゃって、今抗生物質を飲ませたところなんです。だから、残念ながら今夜は欠席させて頂きます。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 泊まる is "to stay the night." The noun version is a <vocabulary>overnight stay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleepover</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 泊まる, so pull from that and you shall know this.

examples.en: I'm making a slide for my nephew's birthday, but I'm a little behind schedule.
examples.ja: 甥っ子の誕生日祝いに滑り台を作ってるんですが、少々予定が遅れ気味なんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 滑る is "to slide," and 台 is a counter for machines? In this case, the "machine" you slide down is a <vocabulary>playground slide</vocabulary>, or just a <vocabulary>slide</vocabulary> for short.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 滑る and 台.

examples.en: I always burn my toast completely black.
examples.ja: いつもトーストを真っ黒に焦がしてしまう。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 焦げる means "to get burned"? 焦がす is the transitive version, so this time someone is actively doing the burning, making it <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to scorch</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to char</vocabulary>.

焦がす means to burn the surface of something, usually blackening it to some degree. Unlike 焦げる, it can be for both intentional burning (a nice crème brûlée) and accidental burning (leaving bread in the toaster too long, scorching your sleeve on the stove).
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 焦げる, so if you know that you know this word as well.

examples.en: The fever medicine slipped in with other pills and I’m not sure which one is which.
examples.ja: 解熱剤が他の薬に紛れちゃってて、どれがどれだか分かりません。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 紛らす means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word <vocabulary>to be diverted</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be distracted</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 紛らす.

examples.en: It was a basketball after all, but it was really misleading. I thought it looked exactly like a pregnant woman’s stomach.
examples.ja: 結局それはバスケットボールだったんですが、とても紛らわしかったです。私は完全に妊婦さんの大きなお腹だと思っていました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>distract</kanji> and the adjective version is <vocabulary>confusing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>misleading</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You know who is particularly <vocabulary>confusing</vocabulary>? That <reading>maggie</reading> (まぎ) girl. She's confusing because she uses <reading>magi</reading>c (まぎ). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.

examples.en: That old screen door is so gross!
examples.ja: あの古い網戸は本当に気持ち悪いね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>net</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is a <vocabulary>screen door</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.
reading_mnemonic: You learned the kun'yomi for 網 when you learned it as a vocabulary word. Take that reading, add the 戸 reading with rendaku, and you have yourself あみど.

examples.en: He is just a young boy who hasn’t been tossed in the stormy seas of life yet.
examples.ja: アイツはまだ社会の荒波に揉まれた事のないただの若造だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wild</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> will make for some <vocabulary>stormy seas</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raging waves</vocabulary>. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, 荒 (the secondary reading you learned with this kanji) and 波 (just the vocab version).

examples.en: Why are you running around naked with only gloves on? You’re such an idiot!
examples.ja: どうして裸んぼで手袋だけはめて走り回ってるの？あんたは本当に馬鹿ね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> is a sack for your hands... better put, these are <vocabulary>gloves</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both the kun'yomi vocab readings, so think of 手 and 袋 as individual words, put together to make hand sacks. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: The novelist finally hit pay dirt with his fifty-fifth novel about dragons.
examples.ja: その小説家は、55冊目の竜を題材にした小説でようやく大儲けすることができた。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: There was a tornado warning and a power outage last night.
examples.ja: 昨夜、竜巻警報が出て、停電にもなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>dragon</kanji> <kanji>scroll</kanji> is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a <vocabulary>tornado</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 竜 just think about how it's a <reading>stand</reading>ing (立つ) dragon, because it would have to be if it's a <vocabulary>tornado</vocabulary>. Your まき reading comes from 巻く, but the kana is pushed into the kanji.

examples.en: What’s the best way to find dinosaur fossils?
examples.ja: 恐竜の化石を見つけるのに一番いい方法はなんでしょうか。

examples.en: "It's Halloween today, so I'm dressing up as a ninja in dinosaur cosplay." "What the heck. That's confusing."
examples.ja: 「今日はハロウィンなので、恐竜のコスプレをした忍者の仮装をしています。」「何だそれ、紛らわしいな。」

examples.en: That philosopher has four dinosaurs as pets.
examples.ja: あの哲学者は、ペットに恐竜を四匹飼っています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fear</kanji> <kanji>dragon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dinosaur</vocabulary>. Dinosaurs are much, much scarier than dragons, and that's why dinosaurs are called fear dragons in Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The crow is seen as an ominous bird not only in Japan but also in Europe.
examples.ja: カラスは、日本だけでなくヨーロッパでも、縁起の悪い鳥とみなされます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>edge</kanji> of <kanji>wake up</kanji> is right before you wake up. And, by wake up I mean you're about to wake up to the truth. But, you're only at the edge, so for now what you see is an <vocabulary>omen</vocabulary>... an omen that will show the truth.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 起 is rendaku'd and becomes ぎ here.

examples.en: This country road is free from traffic jams.
examples.ja: この田舎道は、渋滞とは無縁です。

meaning_mnemonic: If something has a <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>edge</kanji>, it's probably <vocabulary>unrelated</vocabulary> to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How dare you to bring me a marriage proposal from a guy who has less than a high school education?!
examples.ja: 高卒以下の学歴の男との縁談を私に持って寄越すなんて、一体どういう神経してる訳？

meaning_mnemonic: Let's take the <kanji>edge</kanji> and <kanji>discuss</kanji> it. That edge is the edge of getting married. But, when you reach that edge, before you jump over, you have to do a <vocabulary>marriage proposal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am so excited that I get to meet with the left wing movement supporter for an interview.
examples.ja: 取材であの左翼支持者の方とお会いできるのがとても楽しみです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>left wing</vocabulary>, as in the "left wing party" or "left wing politics" or something like that.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 左 is the on'yomi reading, さ. You can remember this because the <vocabulary>left wing</vocabulary> uses <reading>saw</reading>s (さ) to cut down their right wing enemies. Imagine left wing hippies sawing down old right wing conservatives. BBrrrrbbbbbbzzzzz!

examples.en: I feel that I was born with extreme right-wing ideas.
examples.ja: 自分は、極端な右翼思想を持って生まれたように感じます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>right wing</vocabulary>. As in, "right wing politics" or "right wing beliefs."
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 右, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Those in the <vocabulary>right wing</vocabulary> love eating <reading>u</reading>ni (う), not because they like the taste, but because uni is expensive. Picture some right-wing people in your mind right now and watch as they try really hard to pretend they like eating uni as they shovel buckets of it down their throats.

examples.en: The bird spread its great wings and flew into the sky.
examples.ja: その鳥は、大きな翼を広げて空へ飛び立ちました。

examples.en: Please pick the wings you want to wear.
examples.ja: つけたい翼を選んで下さいね。

examples.en: I thought I saw black wings on her back.
examples.ja: 彼女の背中に黒い翼が見えた気がした。

examples.en: The seagull's wings brushed the surface of the waves.
examples.ja: カモメの翼が波の上をかすめていった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: In each political <vocabulary> wing</vocabulary> there are <reading>two boss</reading>es (つばさ). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite or least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.

examples.en: Everyone wants to choose a lucky day for their wedding.
examples.ja: みんな、結婚式の日に吉日を選びたいのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Having <kanji>good luck</kanji> is a <vocabulary>good omen</vocabulary> to have. Good luck means more good luck, right?
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the きち reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I had such an ominous dream that it made me really worried about you, and that’s why I called.
examples.ja: すごく不吉な夢を見たもんで、あんたのことが心配になってこうして電話をした訳さ。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good luck</kanji> is <vocabulary>ominous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sinister</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>bad luck</vocabulary> and an <vocabulary>ill omen</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why do we have to endure their insults, dad?
examples.ja: 父さん、どうして僕たちはアイツらの侮辱を忍ばなきゃならないの？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>endure</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Those who are able <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary> are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The <reading>shino</reading>bi (しの).

examples.en: Koichi beat the ninja fair and square!
examples.ja: コウイチは忍者に、正々堂々と勝負で勝った。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>conceal</kanji>ed <kanji>someone</kanji> is someone who can conceal themselves. Who's better at that than anyone? A <vocabulary>ninja</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: Don't worry, my patient. I can immediately remove your appendix with the sharp blade of my surgical scalpel.
examples.ja: 心配は要りませんよ、患者さん。私のこの手術用メスの鋭い刃で、すぐに盲腸を取ってあげますからね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But it also has a secondary reading you haven't learned, so here’s a mnemonic for it:

<vocabulary>Blade</vocabulary> in hand, you charge at your foes hollering "<reading>Yah</reading>! <reading>Eee</reading>! <reading>Baa</reading>!" (やいば). As the blade cuts through them, you cry "Yah! Eee! Baa!" even louder. This battle cry always fuels your fury and doubles the force of your swinging blade. "Yah! Eee! Baa!"

While both readings relate to blades, they have slightly different uses. は is used for any cutting tool's blade or edge, whereas やいば is a little old-fashioned and specifically refers to the blades of swords or knives, often in literary contexts.

examples.en: While brandishing his knife, he said to me in a low voice, "Get over here."
examples.ja: 刃物をちらつかせながら、男は低い声で私に「こっちへ来い」と言いました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>blade</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is an <vocabulary>edged tool</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cutlery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 刃's reading with the kanji, and you probably remember 物 from so many other words.

examples.en: While putting the edge of the blade in my neck, the guys asked me what it’s like to have people fawning over me all the time.
examples.ja: 刃先を俺の首に当てながら、奴は、皆にいつもご機嫌をとられてるってのはどんな気分なのかと聞いてきたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>blade</kanji>'s <kanji>ahead</kanji> is the farthest part of the blade away from you (since it's ahead of you). This is the <vocabulary>edge of the blade</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>blade edge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 刃 you learned that with the kanji. For 先 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

examples.en: The pitcher threw a peach instead of a ball in the MLB game.
examples.ja: 大リーグの試合で、ピッチャーがボールの代わりに桃を投げました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I was embarrassed when my mom came to pick me up in the peach colored van.
examples.ja: 桃色のバンで母親が迎えにきた時は、恥ずかしかったですね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>peach</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is a <vocabulary>peach color</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>pink</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the vocab readings (and kanji readings, actually) of the two kanji.

examples.en: That part of the movie is always a mystery to me.
examples.ja: あの映画のその場面がいつも謎なんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word mean exactly the same thing. That makes this a <vocabulary>mystery</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>riddle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. No <vocabulary>mystery</vocabulary> there, I suppose.

examples.en: Pretty much all kids like solving riddles, right?
examples.ja: 子どもはみんな謎々遊びをするのが好きだろう。

examples.en: The advert tempted me into buying the riddle book.
examples.ja: 広告に釣られて謎々の本を買ってしまった。

examples.en: Does anyone understand this riddle?
examples.ja: この謎々が、分かる人〜？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mystery</kanji>, doubled? Hm, this is truly a <vocabulary>riddle</vocabulary>. You could even call it a <vocabulary>puzzle</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>enigma</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "If you don’t like your job as a samurai, why don’t you find another one?" "Easier said than done."
examples.ja: 「今の侍としての仕事が気に入らないのなら、他の仕事を探したら？」 「口で言うほど簡単じゃないよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the meaning and the reading of the kanji: <reading>さむらい</reading>.

examples.en: When I got double eyelid surgery done, I was harshly scolded by my parents because I hurt the face I inherited from them.
examples.ja: 二重瞼の整形手術をした時、親から貰った顔に傷をつけたと両親からこっぴどく叱られました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scold</kanji> and the verb vocab version also means <vocabulary>to scold</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: What’s wrong with reading light novels?
examples.ja: 娯楽小説を読むことの何が悪いって言うんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Recreation</kanji> and <kanji>comfort</kanji> are things you do for <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>amusement</vocabulary>. So nice!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you have a bag of 18 liters of rice?
examples.ja: 一斗のお米が入った袋は置いてますか？

meaning_mnemonic: How much can you hold in this <kanji>ladle</kanji>? Why, exactly <vocabulary>eighteen liters</vocabulary> of course! Eighteen is your favorite number, how convenient.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I want to dye this cloth vermilion.
examples.ja: この布を朱に染めたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 

朱 refers to <vocabulary>vermilion</vocabulary>, a bright red color with a slight orange tint, and can also be translated as <vocabulary>scarlet red</vocabulary>. It's common in Japanese culture — you'll often see it on shrine gates and lacquerware, for example.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading can be either the on'yomi or kun'yomi reading, so you have a choice there. Since you learned the on'yomi しゅ with the kanji already, let's learn the あけ reading now.

あけ sounds like the beginning of 開ける (to open). So imagine you <reading>開け</reading>る (あけ) a person up, to see what color they are inside. Turns out it's <vocabulary>vermilion</vocabulary>! Uh… you shouldn't open people up like that.

朱 is mostly read しゅ, but it can also be read あけ in certain phrases, like 朱に染まる, which means "to be covered in blood" (literally, "to be dyed in vermilion").

examples.en: Could I get the red seal of the shogun on this paper?
examples.ja: この紙に御朱印を押してもらえますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>vermilion</kanji> colored <kanji>seal</kanji> is a <vocabulary>red seal</vocabulary>. Just look up the (Japanese) word in Google Image search and you'll see what this is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: On my first day of driving a stick, my car stalled at the top of a hill.
examples.ja: 初めてマニュアルで運転した時、丘のてっぺんでエンストしてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the vocab version of this word is the same as 岡 which has the same meaning and the same reading. Lucky!

examples.en: There are some camels on that sand dune.
examples.ja: その砂丘には駱駝もいるんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sand</kanji> <kanji>hill</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sand dune</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Alright, Mika-san, please go ahead and peel the pear.
examples.ja: じゃあ、ミカさんは梨をむいてください。

examples.en: I tried pear juice for the first time, and it was surprisingly good!
examples.ja: 初めて梨ジュースを飲んだけど、意外とおいしかった！

examples.en: I love pears, but since they spoil easily, I make sure not to put them in my bento.
examples.ja: 私は梨が大好きです。でも梨は傷みやすいので、お弁当には入れないようにしています。

examples.en: These pear macarons can also be enjoyed chilled, if that's to your liking.
examples.ja: この梨のマカロンは、お好みで冷やしても美味しく御賞味頂けます。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same, so this means <vocabulary>pear</vocabulary> too.

Note that 梨 usually refers specifically to the spherical <vocabulary>Asian pear</vocabulary>. When you want to refer to the teardrop-shaped European variety of pear, use the word 洋梨 (ようなし).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: "Turn the light off when you’re done screaming about your emotions." "Roger."
examples.ja: 「感情を吐き出すために叫ぶのが終わったら、ちゃんと電気を消してね。」「了解。」

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shout</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary>. Can also be <vocabulary>to scream</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading of this, just think about how you start <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to scream</vocabulary> when you drink way too much <reading>sake</reading> (さけ).

examples.en: Someone screamed "brace yourself!" on the roller coaster.
examples.ja: 誰かがジェットコースターの上で、「覚悟しろ！」と絶叫した。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Extinction</kanji> caused by a <kanji>shout</kanji>. You are making everyone else's voices go extinct, and you <vocabulary>scream</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> over them. You are making an <vocabulary>exclamation</vocabulary>, gosh darn it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening.

examples.en: Fishing is his favorite pastime, just like his father. They say like father, like son.
examples.ja: 父親同様、魚釣りは彼のお気に入りの気晴らしだ。蛙の子は蛙ってことだね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

examples.en: I’ll let you know how many fish we caught later.
examples.ja: 後で何匹釣れたかお知らせしますね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fishing</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to fish</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I wonder if I should give my newborn baby a bath and wash her hair every day.
examples.ja: 生まれたての赤ちゃんは、毎日お風呂に入れてあげて髪を洗ってあげた方がいいのかな。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just be sure to know that this is the hair on your head.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I wanted to be blonde so I bleached my hair with Coca-Cola.
examples.ja: 金髪になりたかったので、コカコーラで髪を脱色しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Gold</kanji> <kanji>hair</kanji> is <vocabulary>blonde</vocabulary> hair. Makes sense!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 髪 isn't the one you learned. It's actually はつ, but it's getting rendaku'd here. So, to remember the reading of it for this word, just think about how if you were <vocabulary>blonde</vocabulary>, you'd wear many <reading>hats</reading> (はつ) to hide it. I have no idea why you'd hide it, but you can come up with a compelling reason that makes sense to you.

examples.en: "Salmon, what are you doing right now?" "I am doing my hair." "After that, do you have time?" "Nope. I have to do my nails next."
examples.ja: 「ねえ、サーモン。今何してんの？」「髪の毛セットしてるとこ。」「終わったら、ちょっと時間ある？」「無理〜。これが終わったらネイルもしなきゃなの。」

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>hair</kanji> <kanji>fur</kanji> is the hair fur that's specifically on your head. It's your <vocabulary>head hair</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings, 髪 and 毛, put together.

examples.en: Your hairstyle looks like the Beatles’.
examples.ja: ビートルズみたいな髪型だね。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>hair</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> is how you model your hair. It's your <vocabulary>hairstyle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hairdo</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings of the individual kanji. For 髪 that's no problem. For 型 just remember that it's the individual vocab reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: "Isn’t it possible that she really isn’t that upset?" "This is just the calm before the storm."
examples.ja: 「彼女、もしかして本当は全然怒ってないんじゃない？」「ただの嵐の前の静けさだよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I secretly put some edelweiss flowers on my girlfriend’s conical hat.
examples.ja: 私は彼女の笠にこっそりエーデルワイスの花を飾りました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The cannon went off with a bang and the man passed away leaving three children behind.
examples.ja: 大砲がズドーンと鳴り響き、男は三人の子どもたちを残したまま逝ってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>cannon</kanji> is... wait for it... just a <vocabulary>cannon</vocabulary>. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When do you think people would burst into tears of gratitude?
examples.ja: どんな時に人は感涙にむせび泣くと思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic:
An excess of <kanji>feeling</kanji> produces <kanji>teardrop</kanji>s. These are <vocabulary>tears of emotion</vocabulary>, but not the bad kind. You're just <vocabulary>being moved to tears</vocabulary>.

感涙 is an advanced word mainly used in writing. It refers to the kind of tears you might shed when you're profoundly touched with positive emotion, like when you're truly grateful for something or moved by a powerful speech.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 涙 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your excessive <vocabulary>tears of emotion</vocabulary> have <reading>rui</reading>ned (るい) your life. Your friends didn't like being cried at for the smallest compliment or favor, so now they don't even return your calls. No one else you know is <vocabulary>being moved to tears</vocabulary> on a daily basis like this. It's ruining your life!

examples.en: My father works in a peach canning factory.
examples.ja: 私のお父さんは桃の缶詰工場で働いています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It also just sounds like <reading>can</reading>.

examples.en: They’re making a killing selling delicious canned coffee.
examples.ja: 彼らは、とても美味い缶コーヒーを販売して、大儲けしている。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>can</kanji> <kanji>coffee</kanji> (コーヒー) is coffee that's in a can. That's <vocabulary>canned coffee</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>can coffee</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Okay, so from now on we have to call her Princess Aya?
examples.ja: わかったわ。じゃあ、これからはアヤのこと、アヤ姫って呼ばないといけないの？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be used to refer to a <vocabulary>noble girl</vocabulary> as well, as in a girl of the noble family.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I’m here to pick you up, my little princess.
examples.ja: お迎えにあがりましたよ、僕の小さなお姫様。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>princess</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>) is the princess, and you're talking to her politely. She is the <vocabulary>princess</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading of 姫 and 様 combined together.

examples.en: I wrapped a single grain of rock salt in a wafer.
examples.ja: 私は一粒の岩塩をオブラートで包みました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Grains</kanji> are made of single <vocabulary>grain</vocabulary>s. You can also use this to refer to a <vocabulary>bead</vocabulary> or use it as a <vocabulary>counter for grains</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You take all the <vocabulary>grain</vocabulary> and put it in a <reading>tube</reading> (つぶ). Just imagine doing this, grain by grain.

examples.en: I was thinking about whether light was a particle or a wave and I couldn’t sleep last night.
examples.ja: 光が粒子なのか波なのかを考えていて、昨日は眠れませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>grain's</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is even smaller than a grain. It's a <vocabulary>particle</vocabulary>, sometimes even an <vocabulary>atomic particle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The severe thunderstorm this morning caused a power outage, so I can’t use the internet right now.
examples.ja: 今朝の強烈な雷雨で停電になったので、今はインターネットが使えません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>thunder</kanji> <kanji>rain</kanji> is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think <vocabulary>thunderstorm</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 雨, you learned it with 雨天. So you should be able to put them together!

examples.en: The thunder reminded us that we had laundry to bring inside.
examples.ja: 雷の音で、洗濯物を取り入れなくちゃいけないことを思い出しました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading think about <vocabulary>thunder</vocabulary>. Back in the day, it was probably terrifyingly loud. Like the cry of the gods! Wait a sec, the "cry of the gods" would be <reading>神鳴り</reading> (かみなり).

examples.en: When I opened the package there was a homing torpedo inside it.
examples.ja: 小包を開けると、中には自動追尾魚雷が入っていた。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Fish</kanji> <kanji>thunder</kanji> is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a <vocabulary>torpedo</vocabulary>. Load the fish thunder!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How do you usually cook the garlic shoots?
examples.ja: ニンニクの芽はいつもどうやって料理に使いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I paid the deposit on a contract for a five-storied pagoda.
examples.ja: 五重の塔の売買契約の手付金を支払いました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a <vocabulary>pagoda</vocabulary>. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If a huge tornado hit this area, how do you think the control tower would fare?
examples.ja: もし巨大な竜巻がこの地域を襲ったら、管制塔はどうなるんでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>pipe</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> <kanji>tower</kanji> is the tower that controls all the pipes... think of the pipes not as pipes, but as directions things are moving in. You're controlling all of that on a map, and the pipe shows where everything is going and you're changing it to be where it needs to go. You are in the <vocabulary>control tower</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What’s the fastest way to get to the Tower of Babel?
examples.ja: バベルの塔に辿り着く一番速い方法はなんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: バベル's 塔 is Babel's tower. That's the <vocabulary>Tower of Babel</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji.

examples.en: What did you like about the Eiffel Tower?
examples.ja: エッフェル塔のどんなところが好きでしたか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>Eiffel</kanji> (エッフェル) <kanji>tower</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Eiffel Tower</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I hadn’t noticed that there was a loophole in the law until now.
examples.ja: その法律に抜け穴があることを今の今まで見逃していました。

meaning_mnemonic: 逃す is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your <kanji>see</kanji>ing, then you are going <vocabulary>to overlook</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 見 and 逃す.

examples.en: Don’t you think pretending that you failed to catch the criminal is a bit overkill?
examples.ja: 犯罪者を取り逃がすふりをするのは、ちょっとやり過ぎじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic: The thing you want to <kanji>take</kanji> has <kanji>escape</kanji>d. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is <vocabulary>to fail to catch</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 取る and 逃がす.

examples.en: "Come now, isn’t it about time for bed?" My grandfather used to say that to me every night.
examples.ja: 「さぁ、そろそろ寝床に着く時間じゃぞ。」子供の頃、毎晩祖父にこう言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>bed</kanji> is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a <vocabulary>bed</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>crib</vocabulary>. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for 床. You take とこ and rendaku it into どこ. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "<reading>where</reading> (どこ) is it?"

examples.en: I’m thinking of learning how to become an undertaker because it looks like a pretty secure job.
examples.ja: 中々手堅い仕事みたいだから、葬儀屋になるための勉強をしようかなって思ってるんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 堅い is "solid" or "tough." When your <kanji>hand</kanji> is <kanji>solid</kanji> and tough, it's <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steady</vocabulary>. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the two words 手 and 堅い combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: My car was broken into last night and my mac was stolen.
examples.ja: 昨夜車上荒らしにあって、マックを盗まれました。

meaning_mnemonic:
荒れる is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." 荒らす is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying <vocabulary>to lay waste</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to mess up</vocabulary> everything around you.

荒らす is all about creating a mess. It can be physical destruction, like a wild pig tearing up a garden or a robber ransacking and messing up a house. Or it can refer to disrupting a peaceful situation, such as trolling an online forum or chat.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 荒れる.

examples.en: In a wild voice he proclaimed that he was totally “pissed off” at his wife for "pissing" on his face every night while he was sleeping.
examples.ja: 彼は荒々しい声で、寝ている時に奥さんが毎晩顔に小便を掛けてくることに怒り心頭していることを公言しました。

meaning_mnemonic: 荒い is <kanji>rough</kanji>. Double that to 荒々しい and you have the same thing: <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 荒い. Since you already know that 々 means it repeats, you already know this reading!

examples.en: 1 sun is 1/10th of 1 shaku, which is approximately 3.03 centimeters.
examples.ja: 1寸は1尺の10分の1で、約3.03センチです。

meaning_mnemonic: This <kanji>measurement</kanji> also refers to a specific measurement, a "<vocabulary>sun</vocabulary>", which is about <vocabulary>3.03 centimeters</vocabulary>. You'll hear it brought up from time to time to measure things, though usually with more traditional Japanese items.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji! Congrats! Now to remember it's three point zero three centimeters.

examples.en: Is this measurement correct?
examples.ja: この寸法は正しいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: One of the easiest <kanji>method</kanji>s of <kanji>measurement</kanji> is to just check the <vocabulary>size</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dimension</vocabulary>s, and there you go, you've got the <vocabulary>measurement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that the ほう changes to ぽう.

examples.en: My company is on the verge of bankruptcy.
examples.ja: 私の会社は破産寸前である。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Before</kanji> you take the last <kanji>measurement</kanji>, you know you're <vocabulary>on the brink</vocabulary> of something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

examples.en: Do you have any rimless glasses?
examples.ja: 縁が無い眼鏡はありますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

縁 often describes the physical outlines of something, such as メガネの縁 (frames of glasses) or 池の縁 (the <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of a pond).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of the cheese is what we call the <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) <reading>chee</reading>se (ち) because nobody wants that part.

examples.en: Even though the thunderbolt was a direct hit, I was miraculously unhurt.
examples.ja: 落雷が直撃したのに、奇跡的に無傷だった。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Thunder</kanji> that <kanji>fall</kanji>s from the sky is a <vocabulary>thunderbolt</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I have been entrusted to take on part of the large project.
examples.ja: 大きなプロジェクトの一翼を担えることになりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji> is just <vocabulary>a part </vocabulary>of the bird or plane it's attached to. But that one wing plays <vocabulary>a role</vocabulary> that's very important!

This word usually comes up in the phrase 〜の一翼を担う (to play a part in…).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A ball was hit between the second baseman and the shortstop, and both outfield positions are still vacant.
examples.ja: 二遊間、外野の両翼のポジションはまだ空いています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Both</kanji> <kanji>wing</kanji>s are <vocabulary>both wings</vocabulary>! There are two and you have them all!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: IT-related stock prices fell across the board.
examples.ja: IT関連の株価が軒並み下落しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Line up</kanji> <kanji>house counters</kanji> and you'll see that all the houses you've counted are the same <vocabulary>across the board</vocabulary>. It also turns them into a <vocabulary>row of houses</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 軒 and 並 that you've already learned, so you should be able to read this word too. Just note that for 並, the み in なみ is sticking out! While you might sometimes see this written 軒並, 軒並み is way more common.

examples.en: A cute fox suddenly poked its head out of the thicket.
examples.ja: かわいい狐が茂みからひょこっと顔を出した。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: You're such a good child for greeting people properly even though you're still so little.
examples.ja: まだ小さいのに挨拶ができて良い子だね。

examples.en: Greetings are an essential part of communication.
examples.ja: 挨拶はコミュニケーションに欠かせない要素です。

examples.en: I was in the area, so I came by to say hi.
examples.ja: 近くにいたので、挨拶しに来ました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Push open</kanji> the door to the conversation that is going to <kanji>be imminent</kanji> by saying the proper <vocabulary>greeting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>salutation</vocabulary>. This word might also refer to a short <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> you give at an event or ceremony.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: Lately, I've been eating cheese that can be split (AKA string cheese) every morning.
examples.ja: 最近は毎朝、裂けるチーズを食べています。

examples.en: Hey, Kenichi. Your jeans are torn at the crotch.
examples.ja: ねえ、ケンイチ君。ジーンズの股が裂けてるよ。

examples.en: I'm so sad that my heart feels like it will burst apart.
examples.ja: 悲しすぎて、心が裂けちゃいそうだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>split</kanji>, so this verb has to do with something splitting. 

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to be split</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be torn</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to burst apart</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 裂く.

examples.en: The Big Dipper is made up of seven stars.
examples.ja: 北斗七星は七つの星で構成されています。

examples.en: On a clear night, we can see the Big Dipper from our window.
examples.ja: 晴れた日には、窓から北斗七星が見えるよ。

examples.en: This photo is the Big Dipper before dawn on November 3.
examples.ja: この写真は、１１月３日未明の北斗七星です。

meaning_mnemonic: What can you see in the <kanji>north</kanji> that looks like a <kanji>ladle</kanji> and is made up of <kanji>seven</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji>s? That's the group of stars we call <vocabulary>the Big Dipper</vocabulary> or, depending on where you are in the world, perhaps <vocabulary>the Plough</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

examples.en: Eighteen-liter containers are used to store things like detergent and oil.
examples.ja: 一斗缶は洗剤や石油などを保管するためのものです。

examples.en: That store has a promotion on five-gallon containers.
examples.ja: その店では、一斗缶のキャンペーンを行っています。

examples.en: Please stack these eighteen-liter containers in the corner over there.
examples.ja: この一斗缶をあそこのコーナーに積んでください。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>ladle</kanji> <kanji>can</kanji> is a <vocabulary>eighteen-liter container</vocabulary>, which is also a <vocabulary>five-gallon container</vocabulary>. That must be one big ladle!

If you live in Japan you've probably seen these. They're rectangular shaped containers made of metal that are used mostly for industrial purposes, for storing liquids like paint, fuel and chemicals. The 斗 actually refers to an old Japanese measurement, which is roughly equivalent to eighteen liters.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Just watch out for the 一, which gets shortened to いっ.

examples.en: There's a lot of sediment in the riverbed.
examples.ja: 川底にはたくさんの土砂がたまっている。

examples.en: Due to the tsunami, a large amount of earth and sand flowed into the second-floor classroom.
examples.ja: 津波で大量の土砂が二階の教室に流れ込んだ。

examples.en: After an earthquake there's a danger of landslides.
examples.ja: 地震の後には土砂災害の危険があります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Earth</kanji> and <kanji>sand</kanji> is <vocabulary>earth and sand</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sediment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word and it uses the on'yomi for both kanji. This on'yomi for 砂 is a bit less common, and you haven't learnt it yet, so here's a mnemnonic to help you:

If there's too much <vocabulary>sediment</vocabulary>, you need to speak to a <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ) about it. Only a shaman has the power to get rid of all that <vocabulary>earth and sand</vocabulary> and get the river flowing again.

examples.en: The current exchange rate for USD/JPY is 1 dollar = 146.25 yen.
examples.ja: ドル円の現在の為替レートは、1ドル=146円25銭です。

examples.en: The foreign exchange market is a living creature that fluctuates daily.
examples.ja: 為替相場は日々変動する生き物です。

examples.en: I believe that in the context of global employment, the exchange rate risk should morally be borne more by the company than the employees.
examples.ja: グローバル雇用における為替リスクは、モラル的には会社が従業員よりも多めに負担すべきだと思うんです。

meaning_mnemonic: For the <kanji>sake</kanji> of <kanji>exchange</kanji>! What sounds so glorious is really just <vocabulary>currency exchange</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You need to do a bunch of <vocabulary>currency exchange</vocabulary> for your newest investment: <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>wa</reading>sh <reading>ce</reading>lery (かわせ)! Why of course, it's celery that's stored, cleaned, and… smoked inside of a car wash. So go get all the currency you have, we have some exchanging to do.

examples.en: The more options one has in the future, the better.
examples.ja: 将来の選択肢は多い方がいい。

examples.en: In the end, no matter which option we chose, the outcome was the same.
examples.ja: 結局、どの選択肢を選んでも結果は同じだったんだ。

examples.en: I never thought there would be so many treatment options available.
examples.ja: こんなに治療の選択肢があるとは、思ってもみませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: You're free to <kanji>choose</kanji> and <kanji>select</kanji> any of these <kanji>limb</kanji>s, leaving you many <vocabulary>choices</vocabulary>. With all these <vocabulary>options</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>alternatives</vocabulary>, which one will you go for?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
